urn:contentItem:4D3M-SWK0-01W7-60RB-00000-00<published>2004-08-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 17</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>In brief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Charges laid over cocaine haul</p><p nitf:lede="true">THREE men have made brief court appearances charged over the discovery of $45 million of cocaine on a beach in the West Australian coastal resort of Albany. The men -- Bolivian national Jose Melgar Sevilla, 53, and Sydney men Simon Taouk, 29, and David Sukkar, 23 -- all appeared at Perth Magistrate's Court via video link yesterday.</p><p>Winds flip semi and cars</p><p>POWERFUL alpine winds blew a semi-trailer onto its side and flipped several vehicles in the NSW Snowy Mountains yesterday. Emergency crews cleared five separate accidents caused by winds of up to 120km/h, and late yesterday were responding to at least one forest fire in the region. A police spokesman said the semi-trailer on Kosciuszko Road was blown onto its side about 11.30am.</p><p>Khouri book sale forbidden</p><p>THE Australian publisher of Norma Khouri's book Forbidden Love has withdrawn it from sale permanently after she could not prove her life story was true. Earlier this week Ms Khouri submitted documents to Random House to demonstrate the book was a factual account of her life in Jordan. But yesterday Random House said it had not been enough to conclusively prove her version of events.</p><p>Speckled poles win art prize</p><p>THREE tall speckled memorial poles representing the universe have taken out Australia's richest Indigenous art prize. The work, Garak The Universe, by East Arnhem Land artist Gulumbu Yunupingu won the coveted $40,000 first prize at the Telstra National Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander Art Awards in Darwin last night.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:58N5-ST91-JD3N-50PH-00000-00Doom & gloom2013-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 8Doom & gloom

ARGENTINE PASSENGER TRAIN SMASH

AT least three people have been killed and 70 injured in a commuter train crash near Buenos Aires today.

``At the moment we have information about three fatalities and at least 70 injured people,'' said Carlos Grillo Carbo, undersecretary in charge of emergencies in the municipality.

The crash happened about 30km west of the Argentine capital when a passenger train rammed another train that was empty and stationary.

TWO PERISH IN CHEMICAL BLAST

AN explosion at a chemical factory has killed two people, injured at least 49 others and sent orange flames and huge plumes of black smoke billowing into the air in Louisiana.

``We've got two dead -- one confirmed dead and one missing presumed dead,'' said Jean Kelly, a spokeswoman for the state's department of environmental quality.

Some 600 workers were inside when the blast happened at the plant in Geismar, a small town north of New Orleans. Residents said they could feel their homes shake.

DOG CHEWS OFF OWNER'S TOES

A DIABETIC man who dreamed his pet pit bull was licking his toes woke up to find two of his digits had been bitten off.

Roger Brown, of Brazil, Indiana, did not feel a thing because gangrene had previously set in.

Doctors think the dog had smelled the infection and was trying to chew it out of his owner's foot.

Police revealed that, as the pup is a family pet, they were not considering the incident as a dog attack.

SYRIAN REBELS OFFERED US HELP

The US has accused Syria of using chemical weapons against rebels and announced it will offer ``military support'' to the forces battling President Bashar al-Assad.

The declaration, alleging 150 people have been killed in chemical weapons attacks, means Syria has crossed what President Barack Obama has called a ``red line'' in the crisis.

But Washington has not yet decided whether to implement a no-fly zone over Syria, where more than 90,000 people have been killed since the conflict erupted in March 2011.

SEVEN TEACHERS DEAD IN MEXICO

AUTHORITIES in western Mexico say a tanker truck carrying tar has slammed into a highway toll booth that had temporarily been taken over by protesting teachers, killing seven people.

The teachers were protesting at educational reforms that would reduce union power.

COLORADO WILDFIRE OUT OF CONTROL

A MONSTER wildfire continues to flare out of control in the US, growing into the most destructive fire in the history of Colorado and burnt more than 360 homes to the ground.

The Black Forest fire near the city of Colorado Springs also forced the evacuation of more than 38,000 people, as strong winds and high temperatures threatened to send the blaze roaring in to other populated wooded areas.

There were no reports of injuries or fatalities from the fire.

LIFE FOR QUADRUPLE MURDERER

A BRITISH man convicted of murdering four people, including two unarmed UK policewomen in a gun and grenade attack, has been given a life sentence.

Dale Cregan, 30, had admitted killing officers Fiona Bone and Nichola Hughes as they responded to a burglary call near Manchester in September. Earlier in the trial he also pleaded guilty to murdering father and son David and Mark Short in separate incidents last year.

urn:contentItem:44JR-RGB0-0197-G389-00000-00<published>2000-06-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 23</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Secret computer drives go missing</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WASHINGTON-- Two computer hard drives containing an array of nuclear secrets have disappeared from a highly secured vault at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, prompting a top-level investigation, laboratory and Energy Department officials disclosed yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Energy Department officials first learned that the nuclear secrets and other sensitive material were missing on June 1 and have not ruled out the possibility that the disappearance is related to the forest fire that threatened the lab and forced its evacuation last month.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AAP</p></bodyText></section><p>Senior officials expressed doubt that it involved espionage.</p><p> The facility was embroiled in an espionage controversy involving a former lab scientist, Wen Ho Lee, for much of last year. Mr Lee, who has not been charged, has denied passing secrets to China.</p><p> Lee was arrested in December on charges he misused secret nuclear data and is in jail awaiting trial.</p><p> The two hard drives contained material used by the Nuclear Emergency Search Team which is trained to respond to nuclear accidents or terrorism threats. They contain detailed nuclear weapons data needed to render weapons safe in an emergency or as part of a threat by terrorists.</p><p> "It's very sensitive . . . technical data," the Energy Department's top security official, Eugene Habiger, said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5T7Y-JJK1-F031-X46T-00000-00Prescribed burning debate rages as Australia finds there's no time to burn going into peak fire season2018-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisPrescribed burning debate rages as Australia finds there's no time to burn going into peak fire seasonKate Doyle

There is a lot more to prescribed burning, also known as controlled burning, than just lighting the match as a changing climate and environment poses new challenges for fire authorities.

Deputy chief fire officer with Forest Fire Management (FFA) Victoria, Darrin McKenzie, said autumn burning this year was particularly challenging and the state only managed to achieve about 30 per cent of prescribed burning programs.

The bushfire season ran into early April and most of the 66,000 hectares of prescribed burning the state managed to achieve was condensed into a two-and-a-half week window.

"But we were quite strategic in what burning we were able to do. We're always looking to maximise the risk reduction outcomes," Mr McKenzie said.

Despite getting in a few burns in the last couple of days, he said the dry winter for parts of the state, particularly in East Gippsland and parts of the north of Victoria, could also limit the amount of prescribed burning in spring.

"We're still looking for opportunities where we can safely do the burns, but just due to that underlying dryness in parts of Victoria we are probably going to see fairly limited opportunities through the spring," he said.

Fires have already been active in Victoria this year and it is looking like an early start to the bushfire season.

Mr McKenzie said it looked like New South Wales and southern Queensland were in a similar position.

What is prescribed burning?

Prescribed burning is when fires are deliberately lit to manage the land.

With contemporary prescribed burning, the goal is usually to reduce the amount of vegetation avaliable so summer bushfires are less dangerous.

Historically, in the south of Australia, contemporary prescribed burning was usually carried out in spring and autumn when it is hot and dry enough for fires to start and spread but not so bad that the fires whip up out of control.

Why is prescribed burning controversial?

Contemporary prescribed burning has been controversial going all the way back to the first foresters.

Today the main arguments against prescribed burning are that it does not help reduce the damaging impacts of bushfires, and/or that it causes problems for biodiversity.

Bushfire research scientist Neil Burrows, who has been working in the WA bushfire scene since the 1970s, disagrees with those arguments on a number of grounds.

"Bushfires get their severity, or their intensity, or their killing power from how much fuel they burn. Prescribed burning removes some of that [fuel]," Dr Burrows said.

"We've been prescribed burning for 60 years and on analysing the data we can see a very strong trend between how much prescribed burning we do and how much bushfire there is.

"The more prescribed burning we do, the less bushfires we have."

Dr Burrows said in south-west WA they needed to burn around 8 per cent of the total forest region each year to have a mitigating effect on bushfires.

"If we burn less than that, we find the area burned by bushfire goes up," he said.

When it comes to biodiversity, he argued that low intensity prescribed burns were less harmful to biodiversity than the intense bushfires they prevented.

Prescribed burning is not the only form of fuel reduction to take place on our great southern land.

Oral McGuire, a Noongar man from the south-west of Western Australia, said traditional burning practices were the very first form of prescribed burning.

"In Noongar we call it karl-ngara," he said.

He said, like contemporary prescribed burning practices, traditional burning was carried out based upon parameters and perimeters.

But with traditional burning there was a different perspective and mindset around the way that it was practised and its purpose.

"Traditional burning was really about maintaining balance in country," he said.

"The balance was about the biodiversity, the ecology, the environmental make up of the systems and ecosystems that existed on country."

He said that initially, people used fire for hunting but eventually the process evolved into maintaining native grasslands.

"Aboriginal people created grasslands and pasture lands where, over time, they became known and secured hunting grounds for the kangaroo and wallaby and emu."

Prescribed burning and climate change

The aptly-named Deb Sparkes is the coordinator for the Centre of Excellence for Prescribed Burning and said the amount of time available for burning is getting smaller.

"With climate change, what we're seeing is that the summer season is getting longer so it's staying too dry for too long for [prescribed burning authorities] to undertake their prescribed burns," Ms Sparkes said.

"That little window between the bush fire season is shortening so we're either going to lose the window altogether, especially if winters stay dry, or we're going to have to shift our thinking to doing prescribed burning in winter."

The researchers are not operating on a future set of scenarios.

Dr Burrows said he had already seen the impacts of climate change on fire seasons first hand and has been working to mitigate its effects.

"In the past 10 years or so we've actually had periods during a winter when we've been trying to do some burning," he said.

Dr Burrows said he does not think winter burns would have a negative impact on the native flora and fauna.

"For any patch of bush, it's unlikely to get a frequent winter burning," Dr Burrows said.

Ms Sparkes said winter burning can present other issues.

"We have the shorter days in winter, so therefore they may not have that opportunity to burn as much land as they wanted during the daylight hours before the fire behaviour dies down," she said.

"Also, having crews out mopping up in the dark is a safety risk to our crews."

FFA Victoria's Darrin McKenzie said that in his state the shortening burn window was limiting their ability to implement their burns, as well as their ability to manage the impacts on things like community events.

"Because we're tending to concentrate our burning into a smaller window we tend to ... put a lot more smoke to the atmosphere in a shorter period of time and people's tolerance of that is certainly reducing, I think," he said.

Traditional burning and climate change

Noongar man Oral McGuire said that because of their adaptive management mindset and the way that they adapt the practices of traditional burning and cultural knowledge, global warming is not an issue in traditional burning.

"Yes, we've got to shift and change and adapt to what we're doing. But in many cases we are not burning a old growth forest, or traditional systems and ecosystems, or environments," he said.

"We are actually dealing with really damaged environments that are not part of their natural state.

"So part of that process of healing country is ... for us to practice our original practices, our traditional burning ways, to get country in those ecosystems and those environments back to some sort of a balance with what they used to be.

"They are way out of balance of all of that right at the minute."

For the last ten years, Mr McGuire has been working to heal his property on the Ballardong country in the Wheatbelt region of south-west WA.

"I'm infusing it with a lot of ceremony, a lot of language, a lot of hands-on stuff from us as traditional owners and custodians, and obviously through re-vegetation, so the rehabilitation practices and re-vegetating the country with biodiversity that was there - what we believe was there - before it was cleared," he said.

Mr McGuire thinks he is about half way through the process.

"God gave traditional owners and custodians of all of the regions the authority and the law and the right to manage on behalf of the great spirit," he said.

"If it's about country, there's got to be aboriginal involvement."

Is prescribed burning all it takes?

Dr Burrows said prescribed burning is a cornerstone, but in itself does not protect communities.

"What protects communities and what protects the values of firefighters? Community preparedness, people knowing what to do in the event of a bushfire - and even before the bushfire arrives, cleaning up flammable fuels around the houses - [all the things] emergency services advertise leading into the bush fire season," he said.

Dr Burrows said prescribed burning greatly helps those factors, as well as greatly helping firefighters put the fire out.

"Bushfires in low fuel areas, where there's been a prescribed burn, burn much slower," he said.

"It gives people and communities time to respond and to react."

urn:contentItem:7WNY-WKX0-Y9B7-5201-00000-00Qld: The heat is on, prompting fire warnings2009-09-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSQld: The heat is on, prompting fire warningsBRISBANE Sept 22

  Total fire bans are being progressively introduced across Queensland as most of the state faces extreme fire conditions.
   The Queensland Fire and Rescue Service (QFRS) is warning that very high to extreme fire conditions are expected to affect the south-east coastline and the majority of inland Queensland from Tuesday until Thursday, as far as the north-west Queensland city of Mount Isa.


   The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast that north to north-west winds are expected to increase across southern Queensland during the day as a trough system moves into the south-west.
   Combined with dry and hot conditions, grassland fire dangers are forecast to reach extreme for Tuesday in the Maranoa, Warrego, Central Highlands, Coalfields and Central West districts.
   Extreme forest fire dangers are also expected to develop in the Central Highlands and Coalfields district.
   Queensland's rural fire service has advised people within these areas to expect dangerous fire conditions and to call triple-zero if they see even a small grass fire in their local area.
   At midnight on Monday, the QFRS enforced total fire bans through to Thursday in the local government areas of Toowoomba, Western Downs, Southern Downs, Roma, Paroo, Goondiwindi, Maranoa, Murweh, South Burnett, Banana, Gladstone, Rockhampton, Central Highlands, Woorabinda, Isaac, Whitsunday, Mackay, Barcaldine, Blackall-Tambo and Longreach.
   In addition, total fire bans will be put in place from midnight Tuesday until Thursday in the local government areas of North Burnett, Sunshine Coast, Fraser Coast, Gympie, Cherbourg, Bundaberg, Somerset, Lockyer Valley, Ipswich City, Scenic Rim, Logan City, Gold Coast, Brisbane City, Redland City and Moreton Bay.
   People in these local government areas are not permitted to light any fire, including permit fires, once the bans are in place. They bans will be reviewed as the days progress.
   "QFRS are prepared for these conditions and have the necessary teams and equipment on standby to respond quickly if required," a QFRS statement said.
   "Under these weather conditions fires can threaten areas suddenly and without warning.
   "Fires can destroy homes under these circumstances and people should discuss their bushfire plans with their families in case they are faced with a fire emergency.
   "Those who plan to leave should finalise their options and be prepared to leave if necessary."
   Further information on fire bans or how to prepare property is available at www.ruralfire.qld.gov.au.

Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Growth of mega-cities an unnatural disaster</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>* NICK NUTTALL</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HIGH-RISE living and the growth of mega-cities are intensifying the effect of natural disasters, the Munich Re report claims.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In 1950 only one city, New York, had more than 10 million inhabitants.</p><p>Today, there are 20 mega-cities, of which 16 are in the developing world, including Mexico City with 15 million, Sao Paulo (15 million), Shanghai (13 million) and Bombay (12 million).</p><p> Many are developing into increasingly vulnerable areas such as flood plains, low-lying coastal areas and forest fire zones.</p><p> Shanty towns and poorly constructed buildings, thrown up to accommodate poor people leaving the relative safety of scattered rural settlements, are easily devastated by floods, earthquakes and cyclones.</p><p> Gerhard Berz, who leads the Geoscience Research Group, said floodwater could not drain away from large urban areas covered in concrete and asphalt.</p><p> "An intensification of thunderstorms has been observed over heated cities, leading to more torrential rain and hailstorms," he said.</p><p> High-rise buildings, density of electronic equipment and tall communications masts attract lightning, increasing the risks of short-circuits and fires.</p><p> And the massive energy consumption of urban living is making matters worse by releasing greenhouse gases -- one of the main factors in global climate change.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4MY1-P550-TX5K-92GN-00000-00Tears of thanks2007-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisPg. 5Tears of thanks

ONE thing Naomi Tamakuni has learned since her home was damaged in a recent house fire is - you are never alone.

Generous residents have contacted The Manly Daily since the Frenchs Forest fire on January 22, donating everything from accommodation to food, clothing and furniture.

One Seaforth woman held a garage sale on Sunday, with proceeds of $300 going to Ms Tamakuni and her children Connor, 11, and Tara, 10.

Another Seaforth resident offered temporary accommodation. He also donated furniture, toys for both children and clothing.

Ms Tamakuni's former work, State Street Global Markets, is also doing an office collection for furniture.

''People have been so wonderful,'' Ms Tamakuni said.

''Their generosity and kind thoughts has given me strength, just knowing that people care.

''A woman from Bilgola Plateau contacted me, she had spare furniture and things for us.

''She said 'I knew I was keeping these things for a reason, and as soon as I opened the paper I knew that reason was you'.

''I've been in tears all weekend just from the support we have received, it's quite overwhelming.

''A lot of people who don't have a lot are sharing what they've got - and that gives me goosebumps.''

Currently staying with a friend, Ms Tamakuni has filed an application for a new home.

Her parents, Christine and Isaaki Tamakuni, who also lived in the burnt home, may return to Adelaide.

Julian and Diane Malnic, whose home and belongings were completely destroyed by fire, also said they had been touched by the support. ''We're feeling a bit better today, the shock is starting to wear off and there is a sense of a new beginning, and hope,'' Mrs Malnic said.

She said the children - Flynn, 9, Gina-Clare, 8, and Oliver, 6 - were looking forward to starting school today. The Malnics have found temporary accommodation.

urn:contentItem:805X-N8X0-YBDY-R0K3-00000-00IN BRIEF2010-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 26IN BRIEF

Eight dead in race crash

A VEHICLE ploughed into a crowd at a popular off-road race in the South Californian desert, killing eight people and leaving 12 injured.

The accident happened on Saturday night at the California 200 race, said San Bernardino County sheriff's spokeswoman Cindy Bachman.

She said 12 people were injured, several seriously. The race was held in Soggy Dry Lake Bed near the city of Lucerne Valley in the Mojave Desert, 160km northeast of Los Angeles.

Tens of thousands of people attend the California 200, in which dune buggy-style vehicles take jumps and other obstacles on the off-road course. AP

Fire risk to nuke centre denied

A FOREST fire raging close to Russia's top nuclear research centre does not risk causing a nuclear disaster, and the situation is no longer critical, the national atomic agency's chief says.

The Sarov nuclear centre, 500km east of Moscow, has been menaced for two weeks by fires raging in a neighbouring nature park, Rosatom nuclear agency boss Sergei Kiriyenko said on Saturday.

``We can say today for sure that there is no nuclear risk, no radioactive threat and that there is not even an ecological threat on Sarov territory,'' he said. AFP

Japanese leaders avoid shrine

JAPAN yesterday commemorated the 65th anniversary of its surrender in World War II without the ministerial visits to a controversial war shrine.

For the first time in 25 years, no government minister has been to Tokyo's Yasukuni shrine, a place dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including 14 war criminals.

The anniversary is the first since Prime Minister Naoto Kan's centre-left Democratic Party ousted the conservative Liberal Democratic Party last year after its almost unbroken half century in power. AFP

$1b taken from jailed mafia mate

ITALIAN police have confiscated $1 billion in cash and property belonging to a mafia-linked businessman in Sicily, the Carabinieri paramilitary police said.

The money and property were frozen after the arrest of Michele Aiello, 56, who has since been jailed for

15 1/2 years for mafia activities, fraud and corruption. AFP

Siberian tiger kills keeper

A SIBERIAN tiger mauled a keeper to death in eastern China after being left to roam the cage as it was being cleaned, state media says.

Zhan Guanshun was fatally bitten on the neck while cleaning the cage at a wildlife rescue centre in Anhui province on Saturday. AFP

urn:contentItem:47T5-YNT0-015G-W22F-00000-00<published>2003-01-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>US fire crew joins fight</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Kamahl Cogdon</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">'SMOKEJUMPERS'</p><p nitf:lede="true">A crack team of US firefighters that parachutes into remote forest blazes has answered the call from exhausted fire crews.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The US team of 22 flew into Melbourne as firefighters and residents in the state's north-east and Gippsland faced the most dangerous threat since the crisis began 21 days ago.</p><p>More than 3500 firefighters were today contending with 40C-plus temperatures and strong wind in their battle against the 140km fire front, stretching from Mt Buffalo to the Snowy Mountains in NSW.</p><p> Premier Steve Bracks was at Melbourne Airport to greet the first-ever US team to answer an Australian fire emergency.</p><p> The firefighters, from states including California, Alaska and Virginia, are high-country and forest-fire specialists.</p><p> Dubbed "smokejumpers", they parachute into remote areas to devise attack plans.</p><p> They will be sent straight to the Victorian front and used where needed over the next 29 days. The Americans are returning the favour after Australians helped fight wild fires in the Rocky Mountains in 2000 and in Oregon last year.</p><p> Two more US Ericksson aircranes have been sent to the devastated area and were expected to join the battle today. Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman Mike Leonard said the inferno was expected to bear down on towns to the south including Omeo, Benambra, Cobungra and Swift's Creek.</p><p> Weather bureau spokesman Scott Williams said tomorrow's expected cool change would provide no relief, bringing erratic wind up to 70km/h.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5NXV-68J1-F0J6-J05K-00000-00Scientist embodied early CSIRO values2017-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisNEWSObituariesPg. 31Scientist embodied early CSIRO valuesRichard Vines. Written with assistance from David, Robyn and Elizabeth.

Robert Vines, 1921-2017.

Robert (Bob) Vines was a gifted and charming individual, often hilarious and sometimes mischievous. As a CSIRO scientist of 45 years, he devoted his life to deep intellectual enquiry, something made possible by the professional values which were pervasive at CSIRO during his time there.

In his later years, Bob was referred to as "one of the last remaining gentlemen". His gentle demeanour, impeccable tweeds and collar and tie all reflected the earlier time in which he grew up.

Bob was born on February 25, 1921 in Melbourne, the son of Robert Ashley and Agnes Baird (nee Reeves) Vines. His early life was significantly shaped by his father's lifelong commitment to education; Ashley was the founding headmaster of the Scotch College Hawthorn Campus in 1921-22.

Ashley's courage was a characteristic which Bob valued all his life - he had been seriously injured on the first day of the Gallipoli campaign in 1915.

Bob grew up in New Zealand, Adelaide and Melbourne, attending Scotch in 1938-9. He won a scholarship to the University of Melbourne and to Ormond College, where he resided for nine years and where he met his wife to be, the biochemist Vera Hanly.

Bob's working life began during World War II. In 1942, he was seriously burned in an explosion while undertaking some experiments on his own, late at night in the chemistry lab at Melbourne University. He spent six months in hospital.

Because of this event, he became known as an "expert in explosives" and was thus recruited for a position by Philip Bowden, the then head of the newly-established Lubricants and Bearings section of CSIR, Australia's Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, later to become the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, CSIRO.

Immediately after the war, Bob went to Oxford, supported by CSIR, to further his research. He was soon followed by Vera and they were married in Lincoln College Chapel in July, 1948. Their oldest son David was born in Oxford; he was followed by Robyn, Elizabeth and Richard.

In 1950 Bob returned to Australia to work at Tribophysics. In 1954 he won a Fulbright Scholarship to go to MIT in Boston, where he worked with the head of the Chemistry Department, Professor Frederick Keyes, studying the behaviour of inert gases at high temperatures.

After coming back to Australia, he worked on water conservation, studying how it might be possible to reduce the evaporation of water from a reservoir by spreading a thin molecular film of acetyl alcohol on top of the water. This led to many trips to the Umberumberka Reservoir, outside Broken Hill, often with family in tow. These visits cemented his love of the outback. His reputation as a witty storyteller grew from this time.

In 1960, Bob returned to Boston to work with Professor Keyes, this time for a full year in which they conducted experiments on the thermal conductivity of steam and published a set of "steam tables".

The whole family accompanied Bob to Boston, and his children still have fond memories of camping in New England. Bob was offered a job at MIT, but returned to Australia because he and Vera wanted to bring up their children as Australians.

In May 1962, Bob was awarded the degree of Doctor of Science at the University of Melbourne, on the basis of his wide range of publications. This was a significant recognition, at an early age, of

the high quality of his work.

From 1964, Bob led a small bushfire research team that included the talented scientist David Packham. Together they entered into sustained collaborations with the Western Australian Forests Department, led by George Peet. In this work, they pioneered a control-burning technique that involved dropping incendiary devices out of a small plane at a time when the foliage was damp, so as to burn large tracts of forest without risk of the fire spreading.

In 1972, Bob was invited to Canada to be an adviser to the Canadian Government on forest fire research. He spent a year there, with his family, establishing a Bush Fire Research Unit in Ottawa.

From the mid-1960s onwards, Bob became interested in why bushfires occur on a semi-regular basis. This led him to carry out research on whether it is possible to provide medium to long-range predictions of weather conditions, and to indicate when droughts and floods might occur.

He did this work in collaboration with Edward George Bowen, CBE, FRS, a Welsh physicist who had moved to Australia as chief of the Division of Radiophysics at CSIRO, after making a major contribution to the development of radar technology during the war.

Bob believed that his weather work was of considerable economic significance, since the ability to predict droughts would make a difference to farming practices and to the management of scarce water resources. His perspective was controversial, as many people believe that it is not possible to make long-term predictions of weather.

However, Bob was not afraid of controversy. He published his last scientific paper on the subject in 2008, at the age of 87. He had by then published more than 100 scientific papers, spanning 64 years.

Bob had wide-ranging interests in music and the arts, and generously supported Vera's later-life exploits as an art historian, both in Australia and in Europe. He was a prodigious reader.

His gentlemanly manner, shrewd intellect, ever-present humour and unfailing kindness will be affectionately remembered for a long time - as will his tilted tweed cap. He sought no fanfare and had no aspirations to greatness. He also remained overwhelmingly grateful for the life that he had led, right up to his death on March 23, in his 97th year, and particularly during the last two years which he spent at his beloved Anglesea.

Bob's cherished wife of 52 years, Vera predeceased him by 15 years. In the later years of his life, he enjoyed a deep friendship with Shirley Walpole, and with all the Walpole family.

Bob was the much-loved patriarch of his large family, which now runs to nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He was also a wise mentor to many and an inspiration to the large number of people who counted him as a friend.

Written with assistance from David, Robyn and Elizabeth.

urn:contentItem:5XH9-71Y1-F0JP-W0PR-00000-00Climate crusaders exploit fires to push their alarmist view2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisINQUIRERPg. 16Climate crusaders exploit fires to push their alarmist viewChris Kenny, Associate Editor

A forensic look at the past 150 years shows such ferocity is part of this land

Like a struck match in the bush, global warming is the spark that triggers a destructive firestorm in public debate. Heated on emotion, fanned by sensationalist media and fuelled by ideology, it burns through common sense, reason and decency, showing no respect for facts or rational thought.

Climate alarmists are using tragic deaths and community pain to push a political barrow. Aided by journalists and others who should know better, they are trying to turn a threat endured on this continent for millennia into a manifestation of their contemporary crusade.

It is opportunistic, transparent, grisly and plain dumb. Contributions this past week take lunacy to new levels in an ominous sign for public discourse. In this land of droughts and flooding rains - Dorothea Mackellar's "flood, fire and famine" - we now confront an extra injury every time the weather tests us; silly and reckless posturing from climate alarmists trying to prove their point.

History doesn't matter to them, nor the facts. Rather than consider reality they proffer an almost hallucinogenic alternative, pretending their political gestures will deliver cooler, damper summers unsinged by bushfires.

This repugnant rhetoric must be called out; facts and science must prevail. But engaging in this debate must never be interpreted as downplaying the severity of what has occurred - four deaths, hundreds of properties destroyed, lives changed and trauma ongoing. It is only to say this is the perennial horror of our sunburnt country that will bedevil this land long after all of us, our children and our children's children are gone.

Australia's natural history is impossible to interpret without reference to fire; plants evolved to survive bushfire and depend on it for propagation. Indigenous heritage demonstrates an understanding of fire in managing vegetation, protecting kin and hunting animals. Since European settlement our story is replete with the menacing scent of disaster and tragic episodes.

Victoria has suffered most, in 1851 with a dozen people killed, along with a million sheep and five million hectares burned. In 1926, 60 dead; in 1939 there were 71 dead and just five years later at least 15 died. In the 1960s dozens were killed in Victoria in numerous years and just 10 years ago on Black Saturday 173 lives were lost along with more than 2000 houses.

In South Australia and Tasmania there is a similar repetition of tragedy, often during the same heatwaves, only with smaller and sparser populations the casualties are lower. Still, the toll is horrific; 62 people died in the Tasmanian fires of 1967.

Wetter summers and drier winters make the NSW fire season earlier and less intense, with blazes common in late spring. Devastating blazes have been regular, taking multiple lives on multiple occasions in the 1940s, 50s, 60s, 70s, 80s and 90s.

Yet so much coverage and commentary in the past week would have it that the latest tragedy is a new phenomenon. Rare as it is for the rainforests of northern NSW and southern Queensland to burn, it happens.

Back in September, Joelle Gergis of the Australian Nationa University's Climate Change Institute wrote in Guardian Australia about how "I never thought I'd see the Australian rainforest burning. What will it take for us to wake up to the climate crisis?" The Climate Council member wrote: "As a scientist, what I find particularly disturbing about the current conditions is that world heritage rainforest areas such as the Lamington National Park in the Gold Coast hinterland are now burning." But such fires predate climate change: "A bushfire in Lamington National Park today swept through a grove of 3000-year-old Macrozamia palms," The Cairns Post reported on October 25, 1951. "These trees were one of the features of the park â€¦ the fire has burnt out about 2000 acres of thick rainforest country." That is rainforest burning in Lamington National Park 70 years ago.

Journalists, often encouraged by authorities, have written about the "unprecedented" nature of the Queensland fires. Yet newspaper searches tell a different story. Toowoomba's The Chronicle in 1946 reported winter fires in late Aug-ust: "From Bundaberg to the New South Wales border â€¦ hundreds of square miles of drought-stricken southeastern Queensland were aflame." Two years later in The Central Queensland Herald there were reports on September 30 of "An 800-mile chain of bushfires fed by dry grass stretched tonight along the Queensland coast from Cairns to Maryborough." Earlier this year, former NSW fire commissioner, now -climate activist, Greg Mullins told ABC radio: "There's fires breaking out in places where they just shouldn't burn, the west coast of Tasmania, the world heritage areas, wet rainforest, subtropical rainforest, it's all burning - and look, this is driven by climate change, there's no other explanation." But The South Australian Chronicle of February 1915 reported lives lost and the "most devastating bushfires ever known in Tasmania sweeping over the northwest coast and other districts. The extent of the devastation cannot be over-estimated." And in 1982 The Canberra Times detailed a "huge forest fire" burning out 75,000ha of dense rainforest on Tasmania's West Coast.

Terrible as our fires are - often the worst in a generation or more - they are not abnormal in our landscapes, in our climate. A sober discussion in the global warming context might argue that, across time, our endemic bushfire threat could increase marginally rather than diminish with extra rain.

But to suggest the threat is new or can be diminished by climate policy is to pile false hope and mind-numbing stupidity on top of alarmist politicking.

This week, journalists and politicians have wilfully misrepresented claims from NSW fire authorities that they had never confronted so many emergency-level fires at once. An unprecedented number of fires, especially when deliberately lit, has more to do with expanding population than climate.

There also has been much -hyperbole about the fire rating of "catastrophic"; a new category added to the rating system after Victoria's 2009 fires to ensure greater community responsiveness. CNN International went heavy on our fires, saying half of Queensland was facing bushfire emergency.

The US-based broadcaster ran a Nine Network report by Airlie Walsh declaring it was the "first time in history Sydney had been met with such catastrophic conditions". This was typical of the misleading reporting; it was merely the first time the "catastrophic" category had been invoked since it was introduced a decade ago.

Back in 2009, the ABC reported how the additional category was about raising awareness: "Victorian Premier John Brumby said in the last fire season, only five days would have been classified as code red. The new fire warnings system will provide the community with a better understanding of the level of bushfire threat on any given day based on the forecast weather conditions, he said in a statement." CNN also used our fires as the basis for an interview with David Wallace-Wells, author of The -Uninhabitable Earth. He was asked "how dangerous" it was that our Prime Minister "doesn't actually want to tackle the problem". This, in the modern parlance, is fake news.

Wallace-Wells, without resort to science, asserted Australia was -already "suffering intensely" from climate change which, according to him, was responsible for our current drought. He also wrongly claimed our government was not taking any "meaningful action" on climate.

One of my favourite books as a child was Ash Road by Ivan Southall, about the misadventures of some boys who foolishly started a bushfire. It captured an overbearing dread many Australians can smell as clearly as eucalyptus in the bush.

"It always happened on a day like this," wrote Southall, "when the north wind raged, the temperature soared and the hills were so dry that they crackled.

"Fire at most seasons of the year was nothing but a flame that water could extinguish; in this season, on a day like this, a little flame in an instant could become a monster." This invokes memories of bushfires near home in the Adelaide foothills and trepidatious summer days on my uncle's farm in the incendiary bluegum country of western Victoria. In the country and on the urban fringes, bushfire is part of our national psyche because of hard-bitten -experience.

As a national park staffer, and having studied and trained at bushfire management, I experienced one of the Ash Wednesday infernos in 1983. Temperatures well over 40C, tinder-dry bush in the steepest parts of the Adelaide Hills and winds gusting towards 100km/h; this was hell on earth, when fires become a storm and only survival counts.

I missed the worst of it but joined the mop-up - a miserable task amid burned homes, melted cars and the smell of death - -before helping to extinguish blazes over following days. No one who was there will ever say they've seen worse.

People who have seen bushfires only on television can have no idea, and those who experience the horrors of a firestorm won't get into silly comparisons. In her nonfiction account of Victoria's Churchill fire on Black Saturday, Chloe Hooper relays first-person accounts.

"The flames were lying down because the wind was howling through." "It was basically hailing fire." "It was like a jet engine, I've never heard a noise like it and then the penny dropped - it was the fire coming." "Trees ignited from the ground up in one blast, like they were self-exploding." All of this is so lethal, terrifying and devastating - and always has been. It insults all those who have been lost before to pretend it is worse now.

Heat, wind and fuel are what drive our fire threat, and the worst conditions will involve hot, dry conditions and gale force winds across a heavy fuel load. The only factor we can realistically control is fuel - hazard reduction is crucial but often resisted.

While drought can limit the fire threat in some areas by inhibiting grass and shrub growth, the big dry has turned the forests of northern NSW and southern Queensland into tinderboxes. This situation is directly linked to the drought, so the critical question is whether there is a connection between the drought and climate change.

The most authoritative assessment of this came in June from the director of the Centre for -Climate Extremes, Andrew Pitman. (I have inserted an additional word, in brackets, that Pitman and his centre later said should have been included.) "This may not be what you expect to hear but as far as the climate scientists know there is no (direct) link between climate change and drought.

"Now, that may not be what you read in the newspapers and sometimes hear commented but there is no reason a priori why climate change should make the landscape more arid.

"And if you look at the Bureau of Meteorology data over the whole of the last 100 years there's no trend in data, there's no drying trend, there's been a drying trend in the last 20 years but there's been no drying trend in the last 100 years and that's an expression of how variable the Australian rainfall -climate is." Pitman is no climate sceptic. These are just the scientific facts. Yet his comments are fastidiously ignored by most media except to deliberately reinterpret them.

Mostly preferred are unfounded prognostications from people such as businessman cum green campaigner Geoffrey Cousins telling Radio National Breakfast "everyone in this country now understands the link between climate change and these fires".

Or Greens leader Richard Di Natale telling the Senate that global warming is "supercharging these megafires".

What a confluence: media eager to elevate a sense of crisis; political actors exaggerating to advance a cause; horrendous threats that require no embellishment; public fascinated by weather patterns; and information from official authorities feeding the frenzy (revised fire danger categ-ories; weather bureau rainfall records starting only from 1900, therefore eliminating the first five years of the Federation drought; historical temperature readings revised downwards so that this January a record capital city maximum was declared in Adelaide despite a maximum one full degree higher being recorded in January 1939).

When cold, hard analysis of facts is required, we see wild claims constantly made and -seldom tested.

Di Natale and -fellow Greens Adam Bandt and Jordon Steele-John stoop so low as to blame these fatal fires on the -government, dubbing it "arsonists". Former fire chiefs gather to suggest, with straight faces, that some additional climate change action from government could have quelled these fires. It is as -offensive as it is -absurd, but it is seldom called out by a complicit media.

Even Chief Scientist Alan Finkel has conceded that if we were to eliminate all our nation's greenhouse gases (about 1.3 per cent of global emissions) it would do "virtually nothing" to the -climate.

The real situation is even more hopeless, of course, because -global emissions continue to rise dramatically. So, the first crucial furphy perpetrated daily by the virtue signallers is that Australian action can control the climate.

It is too ridiculous to be -repeated yet it is, seriously, and daily. We also constantly hear, as we did on CNN, claims Australia is doing nothing; this ignores our Paris commitments, energy upheaval and the latest report from ANU experts Andrew Blakers and Matt Stocks. They found the country is on track to meet its Paris emissions reduction targets, investing 11 times the global average in renewable energy.

This has not, and will not, cool our summers or quell our bushfires. Still, even if we magically could freeze the climate - setting it permanently at whatever it was in the 1950s, 1850s or 1750s - we know we would still face catastrophic fire conditions in many, if not most, fire seasons.

Many commentators this week have done what they often do when the green left over-reaches; they say the debate has gone too far at either end.

This is intellectually dishonest; one side of this argument urges getting on with the hard task of battling our brutal and ever-present bushfire threat, the other side is playing inane and opportunistic politics.

No one has cut through the nonsense and sanctimony better than The Weekend Australian's cartoonist, Johannes Leak. He has given us the brattish little arsonist sitting on his mother's lap being told, "Don't blame yourself darling, that bushfire you lit was caused by climate change." Then there was "Total Fire Bandt" who was fighting bushfires by installing solar panels while others confronted the flames. And Leak showed the Greens sacrificing the economy in a pointlessly pagan attempt to appease an -ominous blaze.The overwhelming majority of Australians, who comprehend the omnipresent bushfire threat, would agree with these points. But our debate is shaped by a media/political class far removed from practical realities, more afraid of the chill winds of the -zeitgeist than a blistering hot northerly.

urn:contentItem:588S-HS81-F0JP-W3SD-00000-00No place for playtime in breathtaking Beijing2013-04-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 8No place for playtime in breathtaking BeijingLEO LEWIS

Smog has the capital's residents resigned to a life indoors

MY daughter Kirin has lived in Beijing her whole life, but her paranoid parents won't let her go outside.

During Kirin's nine weeks on the planet, Beijing's air has yet to spend a full 24 hours within World Health Organisation recommended limits. In that same period, her brother, who is three, has only once been allowed outside without a pollution mask.

Every morning, before the curtains are drawn back to reveal the invariably depressing answer, his waking words are: ``Is the air too bad today?''

Most days this year have been unsafe for precious infant bronchioles and, on numerous occasions, the air has breached levels of awfulness equivalent to standing downwind of a forest fire.

Quackery, self-appointed expertise and false analogies abound on this subject -- particularly in the white-hot lunacy of the expat internet forums.

A level-headed pediatrician, however, tells us that if the boy were allowed to fill his lungs with unfiltered Beijing air every day he might as well be standing in an airport smoking lounge.

In air quality terms, China's capital has endured an unusually dreadful start to the year. There have only been a few daylight hours in which the air has been as ``good'' as Central London at rush hour.

Weather phenomena, along with coal-burning homes and power stations, have always given Beijing's air a distinct haze and an acrid tang. A more sinister and invisible threat is posed by PM2.5 particles -- the smallest, 2.5 micrometre grade of particulate matter that can work its way deep into respiratory systems young and old. The World Health Organisation reckons anything above 25 PM2.5 particles per cubic metre is unacceptable. As this article was being written, the reading for Beijing climbed from 175 to 213.

Since the start of the year, weekend after frustrated, wall-climbing weekend has passed by without any outdoor activity for the family. The sun shines, tauntingly, through the ochre sky, but my son is doomed to another day on the pathetic climbing-frame/swing combination that sits between the sofa and TV.

At the now notorious peak of Beijing's ``airpocalypse'' in late January, the PM2.5 index hit 886. Players in a regular Wednesday night football game involving foreign journalists and diplomats agreed a PM2.5 ranking above 301 (``Healthy individuals should avoid outdoor activities'') should trigger a brief discussion on whether to proceed.

Analysis of disease figures from 2010 suggests air pollution caused 1.2 million premature deaths in China. This is a slow-motion health crisis, say environmental experts, and any serious solutions will require years to take effect. Many foreigners are not waiting around. A growing number of Western companies report difficulties filling positions in Beijing. The Chinese public, increasingly wearing masks in the street, is also finding its patience wearing very thin. Urbanisation may be the great engine of China's future, but if it is carried out haphazardly the smog traps will become bigger and more entrenched.

The speed of China's economic growth and languid government response means the problem is bound to get worse: coal is the fuel overwhelmingly driving the country's 7.5 per cent annual GDP expansion, and will continue to do so until an alternative is installed.

urn:contentItem:4MFR-8980-TWT8-W2M0-00000-00SA: Firefighter hurt in truck rollover2006-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSSA: Firefighter hurt in truck rolloverADELAIDE Nov 29

  A Country Fire Service (CFS) firefighter was injured when a fire truck rolled over as crews battled to contain a blaze in South Australia's mid-north today.


   The CFS said the firefighter was taken to the local Jamestown Hospital after the incident and was expected to be transferred to Adelaide for treatment.
   The extent of the person's injuries were yet to be confirmed.
   Two other firefighters in the truck at the time were unhurt.
   The crew had been involved in containing a blaze burning since yesterday near the Bundaleer Forest.
   CFS assistant chief officer Rob Sandford said the crash involved a crew from Mt Bryan.
   "The appliance and firefighters were mopping up on the fireground at a fire to the south of Bundaleer Forest in the mid-north," Mr Sandford said.
   "There were three firefighters on board the vehicle at the time of the rollover.
   "Only one sustained injuries."
   Mr Sandford said the CFS would cooperate fully with any investigation of the crash by SafeWork SA.
   The Bundaleer Forest fire was brought under control today after destroying about 120 hectares of scrub.
   A blaze which burnt out 2,600 hectares of the Hincks Conservation Park on the eastern Eyre Peninsula was also contained.
   However, still going were a series of fires in the SA Riverland near Waikerie which had destroyed 11,000 hectares.
   There were no reports of any damage to property.
   The CFS said about 100 firefighters were in that area and were yet to contain the situation.
   Firefighters across SA were on high alert today with temperatures in Adelaide tipped to reach 38 degrees and go even higher in some country centres.
   A spokeswoman said the CFS was worried by forecasts of dry thunderstorms moving into the north-west and north-eastern areas of SA later today.
   "We're certainly not over the worst of the conditions yet," she said.
   "So it's still fingers crossed."

urn:contentItem:4MH9-6XW0-TX5N-1368-00000-00Suburbs choke as2006-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisPg. 6Suburbs choke asforest burns downByJUDITH MAIZEY

THOUSANDS of residents from Jimboomba to Loganholme woke to a thick blanket of smoke from a massive forest fire near Logan Village last week.

The fire, believed to have been deliberately lit, destroyed 770ha in part of the old Hancock's Pine Forest earmarked for the Yarrabilba residential estate.

Smoke from the blaze also stopped traffic on Waterford-Tamborine Rd when visibility dropped to zero.

Loganholme resident Robyn McTaggart said the smell of smoke woke her about 3am on Wednesday.

''It was absolutely putrid and I had to close all the windows,'' she said.

Mrs McTaggart said she thought the smell was coming from an industrial fire.

Queensland Rural Fire Service Beaudesert group officer Karen Mason said the Logan Village fire began about 10.30am on Tuesday.

''It's thought there may have been a small burn from the night before that flared up again,'' she said.

Mrs Mason said rural fire brigades from Tamborine and Biddaddaba back-burned around tracks through the forest.

She said there was a lot of vegetation to burn in the area before summer.

''It's not looking all that great,'' she said.

''It reminds me of the summer of 2000 when there was about the same fuel and temperatures around and we had a fair few fires.''

Mrs Mason said the bad smell could have been caused by burning tyres, car bodies and rubbish that was regularly dumped in the forest instead of the tip.

Tamborine Rural Fire Brigade first officer Gary Healey said it had been a couple of years since a fire had been through that section of the forest, and there was a lot of regrowth.

''There's also a lot of oil in the black wattle trees and they'd throw off a lot of black smoke,'' he said.

Mr Healey suspected a dumped car being torched may have started the fire.

Pg. 3</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Local heroes return from hot US assignment</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Simone Pitsis</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JET-LAGGED and fatigued, five West Australian firefighters arrived home in Perth yesterday after battling the worst-ever bushfire season in the US.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> With up to 900 US firefighters under their command, the West Australians were part of a 48-member contingent from Australia and New Zealand sent to assist American authorities battle an extensive forest fire in Oregon and north California.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>More than 6000 firefighters have worked continuously since the fire started on July 13.</p><p> The Australian contingent spent six weeks helping contain the largest wildfire in Oregon, which so far has burnt out 202,169ha at a cost of $US146million ($265million).</p><p> The West Australian team included Fire and Emergency Services Authority officers Glenn Tunstead and Gary Kennedy, and Department of Conservation and Land Management officers Mike Cantelo, Greg Standing and Brian Moss.</p><p> Mr Kennedy said the operational skills and experience of the Australians were greatly appreciated by the Americans, who had struggled to contain the fire from the beginning.</p><p> "We were thrown into a totally different environment," he said.</p><p> "The terrain, type of fire, amount of people that were involved in fighting the fires, the aerial suppression that was used -- there were a lot of different terminologies, techniques we had to learn. But at the end of the day it isn't that much different to the way we work."</p><p> Nick Devine, operational director of FESA, said the skills learned by the West Australian firefighters would be applied to their work at home where possible.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:46M4-SFM0-015G-V3BY-00000-00<published>2002-08-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Beetle to beat weed</p><p nitf:lede="true"> SCIENTISTS are using a new weapon in the fight against Paterson's Curse -- a beetle no bigger than a ladybird. The Paterson's Curse flea beetle is being collected from sites in northern Victoria and re-distributed to areas of infestation.</p><p>Scientists believe the beetle can play a major role in combating the noxious weed.</p><p> Road, bridges plea</p><p> VICTORIA's ageing infrastructure is in urgent need of renewal. That's the message from the Institution of Engineers Australia, which is set to release an action agenda on the state's roads, bridges and other infrastructure. The Victorian Division of the Institution will launch the report, An Agenda for Advancing Victoria's Infrastructure, next week.</p><p> Bush 'users' hit out</p><p> BUSH walkers and bird watchers have hit out at opponents of new box-ironbark forest national parks who call themselves "bush users". The Federation of Victorian Walking Clubs and the Birds Australia Victorian Group say they are also bush users but are fully behind new national parks. They claim other groups calling themselves bush users often have key timber or mining industry members as their spokespeople.</p><p> Forest fire warning</p><p> EAST GIPPSLAND independent MP Craig Ingram has raised concerns that Australia's fire management regimes are mirroring those of the US forest service. Mr Ingram said the devastating fires that have swept across the US in the past few years should send a clear message to Australia that forest thinning and undergrowth clearing must be undertaken to minimise the risk of destructive fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49SX-PWM0-0045-53J5-00000-00<published>2003-10-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Flare in '72 took two days to kill</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Megan Doherty</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A fire which broke out in the Brindabella Ranges west of Canberramore than 30 years ago in weather conditions similar to those of January 8 this year was brought under control by firefighterswithin two days, a coronial inquiry heard yesterday.CSIRO fire behaviour expert Phil Cheney said the Pago fire started east of Bulls Head in an area now part of Namadgi National Park on December 21, 1972.</p><p>He told the ACT coronial inquiry and inquest into the January bushfires that the conditions then were similar to January 8 this year, when a series of fires were ignited in Canberra and NSW. The Canberra Airport on that day in 1972 recorded a 35 degree temperature, 15 per cent humidity, winds of 32km/h, a Forest Fire Danger Index readingof extreme, and a drought index reading of 103. The fire broke out in an area of alpine ash forests containing fuels up to 40 tonnes a hectare, Mr Cheney said.He said the Pago fire "had the potential to burn into Canberra if it wasn't brought under control".Thefire was detected at 3.07pm and an initial attack by a light unit at 3.30pm failed.Bulldozers and support tankers were deployed by 6pm.Mr Cheney said the fire was "controlled overnight with a combined attack with bulldozers, tankers, hand tool attack and burning out".The fire was "held [back] during periods of very high to extreme fire danger on the followingtwo days", led by experiencedforestry firefighters MorrisFranklin and Bill Bates.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:46C8-RJ00-015H-935R-00000-00<published>2002-07-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:47:39Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>QUICK NEWS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">New Indian</p><p nitf:lede="true">president</p><p nitf:lede="true">A. P. J. Abdul Kalam, a 70-year-old missile scientist who advocates nuclear weapons as a war deterrent, was sworn in yesterday as India's president. Kalam was elected last Thursday.</p><p>Although his post is largely ceremonial the president often plays a crucial role. If there is a hung parliament his verdict is final, and he can call elections or decide which party gets the chance to form a government.</p><p>Fire threatens</p><p>old trees</p><p>HUNDREDS of firefighters struggled in erratic winds and rugged terrain yesterday to save centuries-old giant sequoias from a forest fire in California. Investigators arrested a woman whose campfire may have started the blaze, which burned more than 20,000ha.</p><p>Kisses give</p><p>game away</p><p>A LACKLUSTRE kiss tipped off Philippine immigration officials that an Italian couple trying to enter the country were actually Iranians with fake passports. Ahmad Aony, 47, and Zolikha Rosatami, 30, arrived in Manila on Tuesday from Bangkok and were kissing all the way to the immigration counter at the airport. But immigration officers became suspicious because "there was an unmistakable lack of lustre" in the eyes of Rosatami while kissing Aony.</p><p>Ecstasy scare</p><p>for boy, 3</p><p>A BRITISH boy aged three was recovering yesterday after taking what is thought to have been a pill containing the drug ecstasy. The child was conscious in a London hospital after being found in a "limp" condition. It was believed he mistook an ecstasy tablet for a lolly. A man believed to be his father was arrested.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fire cuts $5m from Forestry's bottom line</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DANNY ROSE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A MASSIVE forest fire ripped through Forestry Tasmania's balance sheet, costing the firm almost $5 million and prompting it to go cap in hand to Treasury.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The blaze, which raged through 70,000ha of North-West forest last summer, was highlighted as a significant factor in Forestry Tasmania's latest annual report which was released yesterday.</p><p>In the report, ForestryTasmania chairman Laurie Wilson labelled halting the fire a "major effort" and said "the financial results for 2003-04 have been impacted by this redirection and deployment of key resources".</p><p>"The largest single fire in over a decade occurred in North-West Tasmania mostly on lands of other tenure and our staff and contractors fought for over eight weeks to contain this blaze," he said.</p><p>"This wildfire could have had devastating impact on both wood production and extensive areas of parks with World Heritage values."</p><p>Forestry put the cost of fire suppression for the period at $4.9 million, up from $1.6 million in 2002-03 and just $102,000 the year before.</p><p>Other documents tabled in Parliament yesterday, relating to money withdrawn from the consolidated fund, show $3.4 million was given to ForestryTasmania in 2003- 04 for "higher-than-average wildfire fighting costs".</p><p>Forestry had operating revenues of $191.5 million, expenditure of $175 million and earnings before interest and tax of $24.6 million in 2003-04.</p><p>Meanwhile, a Bill to withdraw ForestryTasmania's automatic exemption from Freedom of Information laws was passed by the Lower House yesterday.</p><p> The exemption, which the Government had found increasingly difficult to defend against secrecy claims from pro-conservationist groups, was scrapped with the passage of a reform Bill.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:7VH4-C960-Y9B7-51YT-00000-00Vic: Bushfires moved with phenomenal speed, commission told2009-04-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Bushfires moved with phenomenal speed, commission toldMichelle DraperMELBOURNE April 20

  The bushfires moved with such ferocity and phenomenal speed, spotting kilometres ahead and throwing atomic-force fireballs, that it was impossible to predict its path and warn communities in the firing line.


   This was the miserable picture of helplessness painted by Jack Rush, QC, the counsel assisting the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission, about the events of February 7.
   In his opening address to the commission, held in the Victorian County Court on Monday, Mr Rush outlined the evidence to be presented when the formal hearings begin on May 11.
   Countless harrowing stories have already been told about victims of the worst bushfires in Australia's history, which claimed 173 lives.
   There were those who survived, fleeing in cars through walls of flames, or sheltering in houses that crumbled around their ears.
   Those who lived to tell their tales also spoke of others who perished in unimaginable circumstances.
   But Mr Rush verbalised what many already knew, or had experienced, as they battled for survival when fire tore through their towns and communities: warnings were inadequate and the fire was completely unpredictable, even indefensible.
   The fire danger on February 7 was predicted to have the potential to produce fires of such intensity "that it could not be imagined by our generation", Mr Rush told the commission.
   He said the commission would hear evidence that an index measuring the degree of fire danger, the McArthur Forest Fire Index, reached 120 to 180 on February 7.
   Anything higher than 50 is considered extreme.
   Mr Rush said the commission would also hear the system of communicating warnings did not cope on February 7, but fell behind the advancing fires.
   People knew February 7 would be a day of extreme fire risk but did not understand that fires on such a day could potentially not be fought, the commission will also hear.
   Mr Rush said evidence would suggest accurate and timely information was not available, raising questions about the policy to stay and defend property or leave.
   He said even by midday on February 7, there was still no sign of fire in some parts of Victoria that would be impacted later that day.
   "Why would a resident of any of the fire-affected regions implement the 'go' part of the policy if they were not aware of any fire threat?"

urn:contentItem:5DDH-2781-F031-X003-00000-00Climate Council warns bushfires becoming more frequent and severe with climate change2014-10-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisThe World Today1:03 PM AESTABCBarney PorterClimate Council warns bushfires becoming more frequent and severe with climate change

NICK GRIMM: A report by the Climate Council has found bushfires across south-eastern Australia are becoming increasingly intense, and that the economic cost of major outbreaks is likely to triple by the middle of this century.

The report has laid the blame on climate change, which it says is increasing the frequency and severity of hot days.

Barney Porter reports.

(Sound of archived news)

SCOTT BEVAN: This Friday we go straight to the bushfires emergency gripping New South Wales. It's been described as the worst bushfire crisis in the state in more than a decade. Sydney was surrounded by a ring of fire: 100 blazes are still burning; more than 30 of them are dangerously out of control...

ELEANOR HALL: But we begin today in Victoria where some communities north of Melbourne are still at risk from the bushfires which destroyed around 20 homes yesterday.

Thousands of fire fighters are involved in efforts to contain the dozens of fires which are burning uncontained across the state.

BARNEY PORTER: These may yet become the standard type of reports we hear at the beginning of each fire season.

A new report by the Climate Council has found the risk of major fires across the nation's south-east has been exacerbated by a long-term drying trend.

Amanda McKenzie is the council's CEO.

AMANDA MCKENZIE: What we found is that extreme fire weather had increased over the last 30 years in New South Wales, and that this obviously has strong risks for the state.

The bush fire season has also lengthened, so it's now starting earlier and lasting longer. Fire weather's extending into spring and into autumn.

BARNEY PORTER: And now of course there is a new category of fire warning - one of catastrophic conditions.

Is that another indication that fires are becoming more severe?

AMANDA MCKENZIE: Yes, that's a worrying development that happened after the Black Saturday fires down in Victoria, where a catastrophic definition was added to the forest fire danger index.

So those conditions hadn't been seen before, but we've had catastrophic days now in New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia and Victoria again, so it is a worrying development.

BARNEY PORTER: Rob Rogers is the deputy commissioner of the New South Wales Rural Fire Service.

ROB ROGERS: Certainly, if you took last year as an example, it was a very severe fire season and, with some significant losses, so I think it's fair to say that obviously we gear ourselves up as a fire agency for peak fire events, and I guess the driver of those peak fire events could be many things and could be climate change, but I'm obviously not an expert in that to be able to comment on that.

BARNEY PORTER: Why was there a new category introduced in New South Wales? Catastrophic conditions.

ROB ROGERS: Well, the new category was actually nationally introduced, and what it recognised was the pre-2009, historical evidence shows that, going back some decades, there's been fire events that actually breached the other categories, which was extreme.

And, we'd never considered the propensity of these sort of upper end fire events to cause loss of property and life and the review after the Victorian devastating fires, where 173 people lost their lives, said that we need to change our messaging to people when fires occur above the fire danger index of 100, which is now the trigger for catastrophic fire danger.

BARNEY PORTER: He says fire crews are more mobile and there's better national coordination between states.

ROB ROGERS: I think we've got a very, very good system in this country, where we use aircraft; we use people; we attack fires a lot quicker now than we used to, so we put aircraft on them early; we get people winch trained into remote areas.

So, I think there's a whole change in dynamics as far as our response to fire, and now that, considering the potential for increase in the number and severity of fires, are absolutely critical.

NICK GRIMM: Rob Rogers is the deputy commissioner of the New South Wales Rural Fire Service. He was speaking to Barney Porter.

urn:contentItem:7V3D-FV40-YBDY-R0CH-00000-00Horror day forecast Bracing for a scorcher2009-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisPg. 16Horror day forecast Bracing for a scorcher

FIREFIGHTERS are still battling blazes on Melbourne's eastern fringes and in central Victoria ahead of what could be another horror day on Friday.

The Country Fire Authority has not downgraded urgent situations at Upwey in the Dandenong Ranges and at Daylesford northwest of Melbourne, and has warned warned residents to be on the alert.

At Upwey, a fire that started in the Birdlands Reserve on Monday has been contained but the CFA has warned residents in adjacent areas to lookout for flying embers in the tinder-dry conditions.

CFA spokesman Kevin Monk said ground and air crews were working to prevent any spotting of the fire.

He said 400 firefighters were at Daylesford, 110km northwest of Melbourne, attempting to contain a forest fire spread over 2800ha.

``The conditions are so dry that it only takes a small spark and the fire can race off,'' he said.

At Warburton, east of Melbourne, the threat eased after firefighters got on top of that blaze.

But Mr Monk warned that conditions were likely to deteriorate on Friday with temperatures tipped to top 38C combined with strong northerly winds and a southwesterly change.

Premier John Brumby said only rain could snuff out the fires.

He said it was a miracle the blaze threatening Upwey was contained with minimal damage.

Mr Brumby said Friday was going to be another bad day for firefighters, with scorching heat set to return as 1000km of fire fronts continued to burn.

``(It's) nothing like February 7 in terms of temperature or wind but nevertheless we're looking at something at the top end of the 30s and in the north of the state the low 40s,'' he said.

Australia's growing bushfire aid appeals will be further boosted with two massive benefit concerts to be held simultaneously in Sydney and Melbourne on March 14.

Long disbanded groups are reuniting, a major cricket final is moving venue, and federal Environment Minister Peter Garrett will front Midnight Oil to help raise $4 million.

Several international acts will also play for free. Kings of Leon and Coldplay will perform at the Sound Relief concerts at the MCG and the SCG while the Sheffield Shield final due to be held at the MCG will be moved.

Hunters and Collectors will also reform along with Split Enz and Icehouse.

to;<br/>flame</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CONTROLLED fuel reduction burns continued last week in the Dandenong Ranges as the Department of Natural Resources and Environment staff took advantage of the mild weather.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Parks Victoria Ranger Lex Wade said since the end of the CFA-declared fire danger period on March 11, the department had carried out fuel reduction burns on the western face of the Dandenong Ranges below Kalorama and in the Olinda State Forest.</p><p>Fire is often used as a tool to rid bushland of leaves, twigs, grass and bark that increase the intensity and spread of wild fires.</p><p> It also allows firefighters to clear areas that could act as a fire-break.</p><p> Mr Wade said fuel reduction burning was a "very precise science" that required the right conditions to ensure fires did not get out of control.</p><p> For that reason the milder weather in autumn provided the optimum opportunity, he said.</p><p> Mr Wade said residents should be preparing their properties to ensure they were always ready in case of bushfire.</p><p> "If you live in the Dandenongs, preparation for wildfire should be a 12-month-a-year thing," Mr Wade said.</p><p> "There is no value at all in cleaning your gutters as the fire is coming up the hill."</p><p> Mr Wade said people doing fuel reduction burns on their own properties should remember to keep fires small and manageable, have a water supply handy and never leave fires unattended unless they were absolutely sure they were safe.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4R9X-MJP0-TX5J-V0W9-00000-00Fireys battling raging bushfires from state's east to west Summer curse flares2007-12-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:47:39ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Fireys battling raging bushfires from state's east to west Summer curse flaresSHELLEY MARKHAM

FIREFIGHTERS have contained a bushfire which has destroyed more than 5000ha of scrub in national park in Victoria's west.

The fire in the Little Desert National Park was started by lightning on Thursday as a storm front moved across the state.

Department of Sustainability and Environment firefighters on the ground, with the assistance of four water bomber aircraft, contained the fire before noon yesterday.

The fire, which was about 15km north of Mount Arapiles, had destroyed 5200ha of scrub, a DSE spokesman said.

``Burning out efforts by crews fighting the fire . . . in the Little Desert National Park at Jungkum Track, 15km north west of Mt Arapiles, have been successful and the fire has been contained,'' a DSE spokesman said.

``Fresh crews will continue to black out and strengthen containment lines today.''

Two smaller bushfires burning in forest near Portland, in the state's southwest, had not been controlled.

DSE said that a bushfire burning about 12km west of Hotspur, near the Dartmoor-Hamilton Rd, had destroyed almost 500 hectares of forest.

``A forest fire is currently burning in the Dartmoor-Weccurra area and is approximately 490 hectares in size,'' the spokesman said.

``This fire is not currently posing a threat to any communities.''

A second smaller fire, also near Portland, was still burning out of control 17km west-north-west of Heywood.

One-hundred-and-twenty firefighters were also trying to contain another blaze in the Wilsons Promontory National Park, southeast of Melbourne.

The fire was burning in terrain inaccessible by vehicles in the Lilly Pilly Gully area, about two kilometres north of Tidal River, the spokesman said.

``It is estimated that crews will be working for a number of days to complete the construction of a hand trail (containment line) around the fire perimeter,'' he said.

That fire had destroyed about 23ha of forest.

The Bureau of Meteorology said a cold front was expected to move across Victoria late today, bringing with it showers.
